title-group.article-title: Leveraging illumina iSeq100 for whole genome sequencing of Salmonella Typhi for a resource-limited setting

contrib-group.aff: 1https://ror.org/036xnae80grid.429382.60000 0001 0680 7778Molecular and Genome Sequencing Research Lab, Dhulikhel Hospital, Kathmandu University Hospital, Dhulikhel, Nepal

abstract.p: Bacterial whole-genome-sequencing improves our understanding of epidemiology and pathogenesis of infections. It also allows comprehensive investigation on virulence, evolution and resistance mechanisms. Nepal, recently, has seen some increase in sequencing capabilities but faces hurdles for optimum utilisation. However, these hurdles could be alleviated with strategic use of available platforms. Therefore, this study aimed at performing and evaluating the whole-genome-sequencing of S Typhi using Illumina iSeq100. Six banked isolates of S Typhi were selected, extracted, confirmed by qPCR and then sequenced in Illumina iSeq100 at 200pM. The consensus was generated by mapping onto S. Typhi CT18. These consensus genomes and their coverage parameters were compared to data from HiSeq and NextSeq. The raw reads were also evaluated using pathogenwatch to observe genotype, mutations and resistance genes. The coverage parameters (breadth and depth) of the genomes from this study were compared to the same genomes sequenced using HiSeq/NextSeq. The average coverage breadth (96.81%) and depth (63.75x) of genomes sequenced in iSeq100 were comparable to that of HiSeq/NextSeq (breadth: 98.72% and depth: 69.87x). The genotypes detected, the number of SNPs and genetic determinants of AMR genes were identical across platforms. The data from bacterial whole-genome-sequencing using the iSeq100 is equally informative when compared to some high-end sequencers. Thus, this study advocates for optimum utlisation of available platforms such as iSeq100.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: As part of most infection and outbreak management protocols, several phenotypic and molecular methods of pathogen characterization are conventionally utilised to monitor and control the spread of infections1. However, the conventional control approaches are slow, resource intensive and fail to distinguish between closely related strains, resistance and virulence factors which could be due to limited genomic resolution2–5. Therefore, for improving outbreak investigation, comprehensive information on phylogeny and full genomic data are essential2.

Bacterial whole genome sequencing (WGS) is one of the most promising approaches, which helps to improve our understanding of epidemiology and pathogenesis of bacterial infections6. This approach is already transforming the research landscape in microbiology due to its comprehensiveness on pathogen biology, mutations, drug resistance, transmission, evolution, community profiling, clinical metagenomics and pathogen discovery7. This is evident by the large number of whole genomes stored in public repositories8,9. Further, these approaches have already been known to be used in public health surveillance and control for several bacterial infections (Escherichia coli, Campylobacter jejuni, Legionella pneumophila and Mycobacterium tuberculosis), outbreaks and monitoring the source of healthcare associated infections10–14. Furthermore, high throughput sequencing has significantly advanced the field of clinical microbiology, due to its vast potential in identification of infectious agents, detection of pathogenicity, tracking antimicrobial resistance, studying evolution and supporting epidemiological surveillance10,15–17. For instance, identification of single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) can distinguish the evolutionary changes, with low frequency of SNPs indicating bacteria are genetically similar and recently originated from the same source2. Further, the significance of WGS has been more evident by its application in the COVID-19 pandemic18,19.

Although WGS approach can generate all genomic information, it is only being utlilised in niches, because clinicians and researchers have shown reluctance due higher costs, data interpretation and burdensome process of early sequencing technologies1,20,21. Further, some sequencing instruments have high operational costs, and require large multiplexing to ensure efficient and cost-effective sequencing22. Nevertheless, continuous advancements in sequencing technologies such as Sequencing by Synthesis from Illumina and analytical tools have enhanced sequencing platforms by increasing throughput, improving output, reducing analysis time and lowering cost23,24.

Recently, Nepal has also experienced growth in sequencing potential, with some sites adopting next generation sequencing technologies from Illumina, Nanopore and Thermo Fisher25,26. However, not all the sequencers are operating at full capacity due to technical complexities, supply chain challenges, capacity limitations and funding constraints27. As a result, many studies still rely on transporting samples abroad for sequencing27. Nonetheless, these challenges related to cost and capacity limitations can be alleviated through strategic utilisation available platforms. One of such platforms is Illumina iSeq100, which is an affordable benchtop next-generation sequencer that minimizes the up-front instrument costs while offering simplicity of use and capability to generate bacterial whole genome within the country28,29. Thus, this study aimed at leveraging existing Illumina iSeq100 for whole genome sequencing (WGS) of bacteria isolated from Dhulikhel Hospital Kathmandu University Hospital.

sec.title: Bacterial isolates selection
sec.p: For this study, 6 bio-banked isolates of Salmonella enterica serovar Typhi (S. Typhi) were selected randomly from Surveillance for Enteric Fever in Asia Project (SEAP). These isolates were previously sequenced using Illumina HiSeq and NextSeq platforms, as a part of that project. The isolates preserved in glycerol stock were sub-cultured on MacConkey Agar (Oxoid, Cat: CM0007) and reconfirmed biochemically and serologically. For each isolate, an average of 30 isolated colonies were selected.

sec.title: Processing, DNA extraction and qPCR
sec.p: The selected colonies were resuspended in 800 µl of sterile normal saline, vortexed and centrifuged for 10 min at 8000 rpm to obtain cell pellets. The supernatant was discarded, and the pellets were resuspended in 200 µl of sterile 1X Phosphate Buffer Saline (PBS). The pellets were subsequently revortexed and 100 µl of the resuspension was used for DNA extraction.

The extraction was performed according to manufacturer’s instructions using Qiagen DNeasy Blood and Tissue Kit (Qiagen, Cat: 69504), with a slight modification in the elution step. The final elution was done in 50 µl, which was then re-eluted to increase the yield.

The S. Typhi isolates were re-confirmed by qPCR targeting Ty21a gene, using forward primer: 5’-CGCGAAGTCAGAGTCGACATAG-3’, reverse primer 5’-AAGACCTCAACGCCGATCAC-3’ and probe [6-FAM]CATTTGTTCTGGAGCAGGCTGACGG [BHQ1a-Q]30. The assays were run on a BioRad CFX96 Dx qPCR machine, with reaction mix containing 10 µl of 2X master mix (Quantabio Perfecta, Cat: 95113-012), 0.8 µl of forward primer (400nM), 0.8 µl of reverse primer (400nM), 0.4 µl of probe (200nM), 4 µl of nuclease free water and 4 µl of DNA template. The samples with Ct values < 20.00 were selected for library preparation.

sec.title: Library Preparation and whole genome sequencing
sec.p: The concentration of the samples was checked by Qubit Fluorometer 4 (Invitrogen, Cat: Q33226) using the dsDNA HS Kit (Invitrogen, Cat: Q32854). All samples were diluted to ensure an input amount of 75ng. The libraries were subsequently prepared using the NEBNext Ultra II FS DNA Library Preparation Kit (New England Biolabs, Cat: 7805 L). The libraries were quality assessed for library size and concentration using Agilent Tapestation 4150 with the D5000 HS Assay Kit (Agilent Technologies, Cat: 5067–5593). The average library size was 222.5 bp. The isolates were loaded in two batches, with two isolates in the first batch and four isolates in the second, at a loading concentration of 200pM. The sequencing was performed using dual barcodes (2 × 146 bp).

sec.title: Assembly, consensus and bioinformatical investigation
sec.p: The raw genomic data were trimmed for adapters using fastp (v0.23.2), mapped using bowtie2 (v2.5.1) and consensus was generated using samtools (v1.6)31–33. The coverage was calculated with bamCoverage (v3.5.1), samtools depth (v1.6), and awk (v5.1.0), and visualised in Integrated Genome Browser (v10.1.0)33–36. The consensus genomes were built using reference-based assembly and mapped on to the reference strain S. Typhi CT18. (Fig. 1)

caption.p: Bioinformatics workflow for generating and evaluating consensus genome.

sec.p: These consensus genomes and coverage parameters were compared to genomic data from the same isolates but previously sequenced using NextSeq (S1 and S2) and Illumina HiSeq (S3 to S6). The genomic data for samples S1 to S2 were obtained from the National Center for Biotechnology Information (NCBI) under accession numbers SRR33319078 and SRR33319077, and for samples S3 to S6 from European Nucleotide Archive (ENA), under accession numbers ERR5311412, ERR5311447, ERR5311415 and ERR5375985.

The raw reads were evaluated using Pathogenwatch (v22.3.8) to identify genotypes, number of Single Nucleotide Polymorphisms (SNPs), and antimicrobial resistance determinants. Pathogenwatch is a platform which facilitates rapid identification of genomic markers of antimicrobial resistance (AMR) and provides the latest analytics for typing and epidemiological contextualization with public genomic data21.

sec.title: Cost analysis
sec.p: The cost of sequencing at our site included the cost of library preparation reagents, associated molecular reagents, sequencing reagents (flow cell, cartridge, PhiX) and overhead expenses. For cost comparison, in addition to relevant literature, Genohub was used. Genohub is an open platform for exploring sequencing facilities based on variety of metrices (coverage depth, genome size, cost per Gb and others)37.

sec.title: Ethics approval and consent to participate
sec.p: This study involved the use of bio-banked (or stored) bacterial isolates and did not contact human subjects or obtain data associated with them. The ethical approval was obtained from Institutional Review Committee at Kathmandu University School of Medical Sciences, Nepal (ref: 115/24).

sec.title: Extraction and qPCR
sec.p: The genomic DNA of S. Typhi was evaluated for the Ty21a gene, yielding an average Ct value of 15.14. The DNA concentrations were variable, ranging from 1.58ng/µl to 20.6ng/µl.

sec.title: Whole genome sequencing
sec.p: After reference-based assembly, the S. Typhi genomes were mapped to the S. Typhi CT18 strain in the Integrated Genome Browser. The gaps were observed in the following regions: ~1,033,000 bp to 1,047,000 bp and ~ 1,908,000 bp to ~ 1,933,000 bp and ~ 3,053,000 bp to ~ 3,059000 bp. (Fig. 2)

caption.p: Coverage Visualization of S. Typhi genomes (S1 to S6) against S. Typhi CT18 strain reference genome, using Integrated Genome Browser.

sec.title: Coverage parameters
sec.p: The coverage parameters (coverage breadth and depth) for the genomes sequenced in this study were compared to the same genomes sequenced using Illumina HiSeq and NextSeq. The average coverage breadth (96.81%) and depth (63.75x) of genomes sequenced from iSeq100 were comparable (Table 1) to that from HiSeq and NextSeq (breadth: 98.72% and depth: 69.87x).

caption.p: Comparison of coverage depth and breadth between illumina hiseq/nextseq and illumina iSeq100.

sec.title: Cost evaluation
sec.p: The sequencing was carried out in two batches (two samples in first batch and four in the second batch). When accounting for the collective cost of human resources, molecular reagents, library preparation, sequencing reagents and overhead, the cost of sequencing a bacterial genome on Illumina iSeq100 was $157.69 per Gb when 4 samples were pooled, and $311.24 per Gb when 2 samples were pooled (Table 2). We understand that these costs may vary from site to site and region to region due to factors such as custom charges, availability, vendor, purchasing policy and other local conditions. Further, we observed that the cost of Illumina based (HiSeq, NextSeq and NovaSeq) bacterial whole genome sequencing (pair ended, 2 × 150 bp) ranged, globally, from ~$4.12 to ~$591.47 per Gb37. Further, this cost when filtered for commercial facilities in India (closest to Nepal) was ~$55.5 per Gb, when 4 samples were pooled.

caption.p: Cost breakdown of sequencing at our study site.

tr.th: Cost per sample ($) when two samples are pooled
Cost per sample ($) when 4 samples are pooled

tr.td: Associated Reagents and Consumables (Pipette Tips, Gloves, Eppendorf Tubes, PCR Strips and others)

sec.title: Comparison of genotype, AMR genes and SNPs
sec.p: When the genomes sequenced on the Illumina iSeq100 were compared to those sequenced on the HiSeq/NextSeq platforms, the detected genotypes, number of SNPs and antimicrobial resistance (AMR) gene determinants were identical, as shown in Table 3.

caption.p: Comparison of genetic determinants, genotype and SNPs among genomes, evaluated by pathogenwatch (v22.3.8) for S Typhi.

tr.td: blaTEM-1D, catA1, gyrA_D87N, sul1; sul2, dfrA7
blaTEM-1D, catA1, gyrA_D87N, sul1; sul2, dfrA7
blaTEM-1D, catA1, gyrA_S83F, sul1; sul2, dfrA7
blaTEM-1D, catA1, gyrA_S83F, sul1; sul2, dfrA7
blaTEM-1D, catA1, gyrA_S83F, sul1; sul2, dfrA7
blaTEM-1D, catA1, gyrA_S83F, sul1; sul2, dfrA7
blaTEM-1D, catA1, gyrA_S83F, sul1; sul2, dfrA7
blaTEM-1D, catA1, gyrA_S83F, sul1; sul2, dfrA7

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Despite its potential, the widespread adoption of whole genome sequencing (WGS) has been hindered by various challenges, including high costs, time-consuming protocols, and data interpretation complexities38. The Illumina iSeq100 offers a cost-effective and user-friendly solution that overcomes many of the barriers associated with traditional NGS platforms29. These platforms has been known to be particularly useful when used with amplicon-based sequencing of smaller genomes39–41. Nonetheless, this study provides a practical approach for whole genome sequencing of larger bacterial genomes, such as S Typhi, on Illumina iSeq100.

The coverage parameters in our study were high (63.75x) and comparable to those obtained from Illumina HiSeq and NextSeq (69.87x), though we recognize that the pooling strategy can influence this. While the required threshold for coverage depth depends upon the target pathogen, studies suggest that 40x coverage is necessary for high-quality detection of virulence genes, while 4x coverage is sufficient for target gene detection with coverage depth preferably between 50x and 100x42–44. In addition, other studies have discussed that a coverage depth of 20x to 30x is essential for accurately detecting antibiotic resistance genes45,46. Another study that utilised iSeq100 for bacterial WGS reported depths ranging from 17x to 149x, with an average of 59x, which is still slightly lower than our findings28. Similarly, the observed average coverage breadth in this study (96.81%) is well above the recommended (at least 90%) coverage breadth47. This high coverage breadth is crucial for optimal quality data during bioinformatics analysis, as it helps achieve accurate gene identification46.

The genome gaps observed at the genomic regions (~ 1,033,000 bp to 1,047,000 bp and ~ 1,908,000 bp to ~ 1,933,000 bp and ~ 3,053,000 bp to ~ 3,059,000 bp) correspond to STY_RS04890 gene (DUF2213 domain-containing protein), WP_001197078.1 (baseplate J/gp47 family protein), STY_RS09550 (phage minor head protein), STY_RS09735 (tyrosine-type recombinase/integrase), STY_RS15100 (DUF1460 domain-containing protein) and STY_RS15130 (site-specific integrase)48. These gaps could be the result of genomic rearrangements, horizontal gene transfer, sequencing, alignment errors or low complexity regions49,50.

The pooling of isolates with varying genome size can lead to unequal coverage, even with equimolar pooling. However, some protocols do not mandate equimolar pooling28,51. Further, pooling also depends on the complexity of the genome; for instance, although Escherichia coli and Salmonella enterica (S. enterica) have similar genome size, E. coli is more complex with variable accessory genomes, allowing more S. enterica genomes to be pooled51. Moreover, the cost per run is also influenced by pooling, with the number of samples pooled proportional to cartridge/flow cell requirements. Unfortunately, the number of samples pooled, by the SEAP study, for sequencing in HiSeq and NextSeq could not be confirmed which limits more detailed comparisons.

The average cost per Gb for HiSeq (using HiSeq SBS Kit V4 kit − 250 cycles PE 2 × 125 bp, which has now been discontinued) is $60.65, while for iSeq, the cost is ~$130 per Gb when 4 samples are pooled and ~$87 when 6 samples are pooled38,52. The cost at our site is slightly higher (~$158 per Gb when 4 samples are pooled), because the cost of sequencing is dependent on region, vendors, purchasing policy and local supply chain logistics53. In general, cost of Illumina based (HiSeq, NextSeq and NovaSeq) bacterial whole genome sequencing, at core facilities and service providers, ranges from ~$4.12 to ~$591.47 per Gb globally37. This cost when filtered for India (closest to Nepal) was ~$55.5 to ~$173 per Gb37,54. Furthermore, a systematic review of 2023 found the cost of WGS of bacterial pathogens, including Salmonella, to be between $72.13 to $470.3755. Nonetheless, the sequencing costs would still be comparable when transportation costs are included.

In the context of low-cost NGS alternatives, Oxford Nanopore offers the flongle, which provides output up to 2Gb for ~$90, while iSeq100 cartridge and flowcell costs ~$630 with 1.2Gb output51. Further, the capital investment for purchase of the Oxford Nanopore instrument is also lower compared to the Illumina platform. However, the shorter shelf life of the flow cell and lower accuracy of individual reads may make Nanopore less favorable. Nonetheless, some techniques have been studied that could possibly increase accuracy56,57.

Our study identified genotypes 4.3.1.1 and 4.3.1.2, both belonging to lineage I and II of H58 strain, which were first detected in a pediatric study conducted in Kathmandu, Nepal58. Furthermore, the mutations (S83F and D87N) observed in quinolone resistance determining region of gyrA gene were associated with fluoroquinolone resistance59–61. Additionally, mutations conferring resistance to ampicillin (blaTEM), chloramphenicol (catA1) co-trimoxazole (sul), and trimethoprim (dfrA7) were also observed62–65. Notably, the genotypes, genomic determinants and number of SNPs among the S. Typhi genomes were identical, as expected, across the iSeq100, HiSeq and NextSeq platforms.

Our findings demonstrate that the iSeq100 can generate high-quality, accurate data for bacterial WGS, and represents a cost-effective addition to the genomic research capabilities. The genomes generated on the iSeq showed comparable coverage parameters to those obtained from more established commercial sequencing platforms like the Illumina HiSeq or NextSeq.

We recognise that some comparative cost analyses were constrained by site/region specific cost factors (human resources, regional or national pricing/purchasing strategies) and unavailability of standardized metadata (pooling strategy). A more detailed cost analysis could be performed with WHO’s Genomics Costing Tool66. Additionally, the study only focused on a single bacterial species, which could be further explored. Further, we also acknowledge that on 27 March 2025, Illumina notified that it would end support for iSeq100 along with MiSeq RUO, MiniSeq Systems by December 2029, while still making them available for order until 30 September 202567. Nonetheless, we realise that platforms with updated chemistry are regularly being launched, such as MiSeq i100 series with XLEAP -SBS chemistry68. Thus, future comparisons with these platforms could build upon our findings and provide additional insights.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: The data from bacterial whole genome sequencing using the Illumina iSeq100 is equally informative when compared to other high-end sequencers. We have shown that iSeq100, though primarily designed for small-genome sequencing and metagenomics, is able to perform whole genome sequencing of bacteria. The findings of this study support premise that iSeq100 is well suited for small laboratories with low sample throughput, such as those mostly found in Nepal where the molecular and genomic research ecosystem is still developing.

Looking ahead, the findings of this study pave the way for broader applications of the Illumina iSeq100 platform in clinical microbiology, outbreak surveillance, and antimicrobial resistance monitoring in Nepal. Future research should focus on optimizing sample preparation protocols, expanding sequencing capacity, and integrating bioinformatics tools to enhance the utility and accessibility of WGS technologies in pathogen investigation.

ack.title: Acknowledgements
ack.p: We gratefully thank Jason R. Andrews, Kesia Esther da Silva and the SEAP team for providing accessions numbers (European Nucleotide Archive) for the S. Typhi isolates. We are also thankful to all the research staffs at Center for Infectious Disease Research and Surveillance, Dhulikhel Hospital Kathmandu University Hospital, Nepal.

notes.title: Funding
notes.p: This study was funded and supported by Center for Infectious Disease Research and Surveillance, Dhulikhel Hospital Kathmandu University Hospital, Nepal.

notes.title: Data availability
notes.p: The raw genomic data, from Illumina iSeq100, can be obtained from National Center for Biotechnology Information’s BioProject PRJNA1110744 (Accession: SRX24530188 to SRX24530193).

notes.title: Competing interests
notes.p: The authors declare no competing interests.
